title: First Reserve Extends Its Hold on Refuel With Single-Asset Secondary Deal; Goldman Sachs Asset Management was lead investor in sponsor-led single-asset transaction, which closed with nearly $511 million
text:
Secondary advisory firm Sixpoint Capital worked with First Reserve on the continuation fund deal, according to the people and a regulatory filing.

Stamford, Conn.-based First Reserve initially acquired Refuel Inc. in 2019 along with another South Carolina-based gas station operator West Oil Inc., which it merged into Refuel. The firm financed the deal out of its energy-focused fund, First Reserve XIII LP, which, according to a regulatory filing, raised some $3.39 billion in 2014.

Since the initial deal, First Reserve has expanded Refuel through other acquisitions, including most recently San Antonio-based Action Fuels LP, a wholesale and retail duel distribution and convenience-store chain, and Wag-A-Bag LLC, an Austin, Texas-based owner and operator of convenience stores with Shell- and Valero-branded fuels.

First Reserve is among a number of private-equity investors using continuation funds or special-purpose vehicles to retain ownership of individual companies for longer. Sponsor-led single asset deals, like the one for Refuel, accounted for 25% of the $48 billion of transaction volume in the first half of last year, according to a survey by secondary adviser Evercore Inc. Other firms that have done such deals in recent months include Clearlake Capital Group, Lime Rock Partners and NewSpring Capital.

First Reserve makes investments in energy and natural resources companies across three broad segments: natural resources, equipment and services as well as midstream and downstream oil-and-gas companies. Over the years, the firm has evolved its focus beyond a legacy emphasis on oil and gas exploration and production to include energy infrastructure, renewable energy, energy equipment and services, manufacturing, energy technology, as well as mining and minerals resources.
